column2: Artificial Intelligence and Economic Growth
column4: ~4 years, if you mean doing original research in economic theory with a large proportion of my time; ~2.5 years, if you mean having some particular focus on growth theory or the economics of AI.
column5:
I’m not sure how to interpret this.
I’ve peer-reviewed one paper on the economics of AI.
I’ve “evaluated” around 30 papers on the economics of AI in the course of writing a literature review on the subject.
More generally, I’ve given informal feedback on many research ideas and papers in progress by fellow researchers at GPI, fellow economics graduate students, and people (usually undergraduates) interested in doing EA-relevant economics work who reach out or are put in touch with me in some way.
column39: Artificial Intelligence and Economic Growth
column45: Emerging technologies: social and economic impacts (focus: AI)

column2: Do Celebrity Endorsements Matter? A Twitter Experiment Promoting Vaccination In Indonesia
column4: I am 2 years post-doc, and have been working in applied microeconomics in a developing country context (India) since 2014, and have been working on health policy and communication (with a focus on behavioural science) since 2020.
column5: For the Unjournal, I have been managing editor on one other evaluation, and have evaluated one other paper. As a peer reviewer, I have done about 25 papers, largely in the domain of health and applied economics. I am also currently Deputy Editor at South Asia Research, where I edit papers in economics.
